title: Tuesday, 24th April, 2018

BE11:07am

A move to cut the maximum stake on highly addictive gambling machines to £2 is set to be announced within weeks as the Treasury signalled a deal last night.

Philip Hammond had delayed signing off the move in a Whitehall dispute over how lost taxes would be replaced. However, the chancellor is understood to have accepted expert recommendations that stakes for fixed odds betting terminals (FOBTs) should be reduced to £2. His allies said that there was growing optimism that an agreement with Matt Hancock, the culture secretary, was imminent. “We are very nearly there,” one said.

The government promised in January that the maximum stake on the machines, called the “crack cocaine of gambling”, would be lowered from £100 a spin to somewhere between… [PAYWALL]

tadam Good morning. Update on Shire, please?
DRichi They are boring things. Give me the horses or blackjack any day

11:24 am

Anyway, in the absence of clarity on whether Stryker's back in talks to buy S&Nm let's go through the prosaic business of results previews.

BE11:25am

Smith & Nephew reports its Q1 2018 sales on Thursday 3 May at 07.00 UK time: We expect another lacklustre quarter from Smith & Nephew, with overall revenues of $1,201m, which equates to a 5.2% yoy increase, driven by 1.1% underlying growth and a c4% FX tailwind. The underlying growth rate we expect of 1.1% is inclusive of the effect of one less selling day as compared to Q1 2017, as per the company’s definition. Excluding the effect of FX, selling days and acquisitions, we expect growth of 1.9%.

BE11:25am

This is Berenberg.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

While we expect a fairly lacklustre performance in Q1 2018, we do not think it has much bearing on the outlook for the shares. The key factor, in the short term at least, is the intention of the newly appointed CEO, and the Q1 2018 sales figures should provide the first insights into his strategy. We do not expect a radical change in strategy, but we do expect an increased focus on operational execution or, in simple terms, more detail on how he intends to sell more of the products the company already markets.

Groundhog Day @Maverick: where do you see that please?
nichoman reading through a merger doc a year or two ago, I was surprised by extent to which press actually played a catalysing role -- acquirer saw reports and got involved. would be funny if petersmith, who ever he may be, played a similar role
BE11:26am

And on valuation .....

BE11:26am

We continue to rate Smith & Nephew’s shares a Hold as
we think that on a 2018 P/E of 20.3x for a 2018-2022E adjusted EPS CAGR of 8.4%, they are fairly valued. However, disappointment after disappointment has left investor expectations extremely low in our view. We thus concede that any hint of an improvement in revenue growth toward the 4% level or higher is likely to drive the shares higher. In this context, the risk-reward is perhaps skewed to the upside, even with the shares already at what we would regard as fair value, but with Q1 2018 not likely to be anywhere near this level, we remain comfortable with our Hold rating for now.

Maverick 11:19 *DJ Shire Shares Up 6.1% On Reports Of Improved Takeda Offer

Let me mention ... in our future partnership we would like ambitious provisions on the movement of people, including related areas such as coordination of social security and the recognition of professional qualifications." So graduates may be able to move about but not just any Tom, Michać or Pawel. http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-18-3511_en.htm

Q1 unlikely to be a positive driver, but expectations are low. Following a strong Q4, there is likely to a bit of a ‘hangover’ in Q1. Furthermore, the company faces one fewer trading day and an Easter effect. We forecast a c5.5% tailwind from FX. It is worth noting we forecast the sales day impact separately (i.e. the u/l numbers in fig exclude the impact of sales days except where stated).

...... so, this is a double hit according to The Times (which has set the pace on this story, though because politics is a messy business it's not always been to the benefit of clarity).

£2 per spin limit on the roulette machines plus a gaming tax increase to offset the lost revenue.

BornCynic BE - is there anything you do not know? How on earth do you know that the picture is Stanija Dobrojevic............
BE11:33am

All agreed between Treasury and Downing Street, but statement held back until after the local elections.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

(@BornCynic: Google reverse image search.)

BE11:34am

Morgan Stanley ......

BE11:35am

Taking the mid-point of Paddy Power Betfair guidance for impact in a £2 case (33-43% hit to machine revenue) implies the Treasury would be looking to make up a headline ~£170m of tax revenue from the £450-500m tax generated by machines (ignoring the impact of potential industry shop closures and mitigation measures). If this tax loss were levied on online income to make up the shortfall we estimate it would imply an additional 3.5%-pts of duty on a 15% base. We estimate this would be an additional hit to EPS of 8% for Paddy Power Betfair and 9% to William Hill. In this scenario, the UK would still have one of the lowest rates of taxation among European jurisdictions.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

In total therefore, the scenario laid out in the article could imply a ~27% downgrade to our William Hill EPS forecasts and ~11% to our Paddy Power Betfair forecasts.

BE11:36am

Did you know that the UK's quite lightly taxed for punting? I did not.

BE11:36am

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Less than Italy, which is Europe's biggest gambling market I think.

BE11:38am

And Barclays .......

BE11:38am

There have been so many conflicting articles for the last 2 years with regards to the outcome of the Triennial Review it is hard to know what is and what is not a well informed piece.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

........ Which is a little harsh. As I've said, politics isn't helpful for clear reporting. Things can be accurate without delivering clarity.

BE11:39am

Looking at GVC, WMH and PPB, we do not think this double blow is priced in. If we simplistically assume that the increase in other levies is an increase in UK online POC tax to 20% (from 15%), it would imply a further 7-10% EPS hit on top of the impact from max stakes on FOBTs being cut. We show the potential impact below. William Hill is most impacted on EPS. Paddy Power Betfair is least impacted. We think this news could materially impact share prices today but taking a big step back, earnings will be hit, management teams will have to spend additional time on fixed cost savings and player mitigation issues but the earnings mix for all of the aforementioned operators becomes more attractive, the biggest regulatory risk has happened and over time, the sector will become more investable. In the short-term however, this news will lead to a de-rating in our view.

we thus raise our YE Mar 19E Mar 20E EPS by 2% 4%, assuming the deal closes in September 2018. We increase our multiples-based Dec-18 price target by 2% to 260p (255p)

BE11:48am

EIS derives c50% of its revenue from providing low-speed airborne training services, primarily to the German and US air forces based in Germany. The other 50% is from modifying aircraft for special mission, by fitting the planes with sensors and digital systems. EIS expands QQ's international sales and looks to be a good fit with existing QQ services (especially with Meggitt Target Systems which QQ acquired for £58m in December 2016). In the year to Dec 2017 EIS generated €20.1m of revenue and €5.4m of EBITDA, giving a c27% EBITDA margin. (EIS leases the aircraft it operates so it has very little depreciation and the EBITA margin is very similar to the EBITDA margin.) The acquisition price looks attractive at 13x 2017A EBITDA, especially as QQ expects EIS to achieve sales growth of c20% in calendar 2018, and double digit growth after that. QQ will acquire EIS from its net cash resources and we still expect it to end the Mar 2019E financial year with net cash of £181m, after paying for EIS.

CityFibre has had a weak equity performance since the Vodafone
deal announcement last year (-35%), despite positive news from the industry.

BE12:03pm

TalkTalk and Openreach playing catch up shows they are concerned, and that the investment made by CityFibre since inception was right. Ofcom’s decision to halt the process to regulate Openreach’s Dark Fibre, which would have stymied investment, is again positive. And the ASA’s decision to change how fibre products are advertised (coming in May), removing the extremely misleading ‘up to’ speed limit advertising condition, to be now based on average speeds, is again clearly beneficial for a product that doesn’t diminish over time, unlike copper.

BE12:03pm

Given the long-term
potential of CityFibre, along with the regulatory, consumer, and
business environment all pointing towards full-fibre, we remain
positive for its longer-term performance. Given the cash bid, our
TP comes down to 81p and we downgrade to a Hold. The
bidders believe in the strong potential of CityFibre, as do we, but
believe it is one that is better suited for the private markets.
